sen.j: 松平 忠晴（まつだいら ただはる、慶長3年（1598年） - 寛文9年3月23日 (旧暦)（1669年4月23日））は、駿河国田中藩主。
sen.e: Tadaharu MATSUDAIRA (1598-April 23, 1669) was a lord of the Tanaka Domain in Suruga Province.
Tadaharu MATSUDAIRA (1598-April 23, 1669) was a lord of the Tanaka Domain in Suruga Province.
Tadaharu MATSUDAIRA (1598-April 23, 1669) was a lord of the Tanaka Domain in Suruga Province.

sen.j: 遠江国掛川藩主。
sen.e: He was a lord of the Kakegawa Domain in Totomi Province.
He was a lord of the Kakegawa Domain in Totomi Province.
He was a lord of the Kakegawa Domain in Totomi Province.

sen.j: 丹波国丹波亀山藩の初代藩主。
sen.e: He was the first lord of the Tanba-Kameyama Domain in Tanba Province.
He was the first lord of the Tanba-Kameyama Domain in Tanba Province.
He was the first lord of the Tanba-Kameyama Domain in Tanba Province.

sen.j: 伊賀守流藤井松平家初代。
sen.e: He was the first generation of the Fujii-Matsudaira family in Iga no kami (Governor of Iga Province) line.
He was the first generation of the Fujii-Matsudaira family in Iga no kami (Governor of Iga Province) line.
He was the first generation of the Fujii-Matsudaira family in Iga no kami (Governor of Iga Province) line.

sen.j: 松平信吉の次男。
sen.e: He was the second son of Nobuyoshi MATSUDAIRA.
He was the second son of Nobuyoshi MATSUDAIRA.
He was the second son of Nobuyoshi MATSUDAIRA.

sen.j: 母は藤井松平信一の娘。
sen.e: His mother was the daughter of Nobukazu FUJII-MATSUDAIRA.
His mother was the daughter of Nobukazu FUJII-MATSUDAIRA.
His mother was the daughter of Nobukazu FUJII-MATSUDAIRA.

sen.j: 同母兄に松平忠国 (播磨国明石藩主)。
sen.e: His older brother was Tadakuni MATSUDAIRA (the lord of the Akashi Domain in Harima Province).
sen.cmt: 松平忠国の父も藤井松平信吉であることから、同じ父母を持つ兄弟ということで訳しました。
sen.e: His older brother was Tadakuni MATSUDAIRA (the lord of the Akashi Domain in Harima Province).
His older brother was Tadakuni MATSUDAIRA (the lord of the Akashi Domain in Harima Province).

sen.j: 正室は杉原長房の娘（浅野長晟の養女）。
sen.e: His lawful wife was the daughter (the adopted daughter of Nagaakira ASANO) of Nagafusa SUGIHARA.
His lawful wife was the daughter (the adopted daughter of Nagaakira ASANO) of Nagafusa SUGIHARA.
His lawful wife was the daughter (the adopted daughter of Nagaakira ASANO) of Nagafusa SUGIHARA.

sen.j: 子は松平忠俊（長男）、松平忠昭 (藤井松平家)（次男）、松平忠周（三男）。
sen.e: His children were Tadatoshi MATSUDAIRA (the oldest son), Tadaaki MATSUDAIRA (the Fujii-Matsudaira family) (the second son), and Tadachika MATSUDAIRA (the third son).
His children were Tadatoshi MATSUDAIRA (the oldest son), Tadaaki MATSUDAIRA (the Fujii-Matsudaira family) (the second son), and Tadachika MATSUDAIRA (the third son).
His children were Tadatoshi MATSUDAIRA (the oldest son), Tadaaki MATSUDAIRA (the Fujii-Matsudaira family) (the second son), and Tadachika MATSUDAIRA (the third son).

sen.j: 官位は従五位下、伊賀国守。
sen.e: His official rank was Jugoinoge Iga no kuni no Kami (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade, Officer in charge of regional administration in Iga Province).
His official rank was Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade), the Governor of Iga Province.
sen.cmt: 「従五位下、伊賀国守」の表記を修正
sen.e: His official rank was Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade), the Governor of Iga Province.

sen.j: 慶長3年（1598年）、下総国布川にて生まれる。
sen.e: In 1598, he was born in Fukawa, Shimousa Province.
In 1598, he was born in Fukawa, Shimosa Province.
In 1598, he was born in Fukawa, Shimosa Province.

sen.j: 徳川秀忠から一字をもらって忠晴と名乗った。
sen.e: He was named as Tadaharu ("忠晴") by incorporating one Chinese character used by Hidetada TOKUGAWA ("徳川秀忠").
He was named as Tadaharu ("忠晴") by incorporating one Chinese character used by Hidetada TOKUGAWA ("徳川秀忠").
He was named as Tadaharu ("忠晴") by incorporating one Chinese character used by Hidetada TOKUGAWA ("徳川秀忠").

sen.j: 元和 (日本)元年（1615年）に叙任される。
sen.e: He was appointed Jugoinoge Iga no kuni no Kami in 1615.
He was appointed Jugoinoge, the Governor of Iga Province in 1615.
sen.cmt: Iga no kuni no Kami→the Governor of Iga Provinceとしました。
sen.e: He was appointed Jugoinoge, the Governor of Iga Province in 1615.

sen.j: 元和5年（1619年）に常陸国で土浦藩3万5000石の内から2000石を父・松平信吉から分知される。
sen.e: In 1619, he received 2,000 koku from his father, Nobuyoshi MATSUDAIRA, who was the lord of the Tsuchiura Domain of 35,000 koku, in Hitachi Province.
In 1619, he received 2,000 koku from his father, Nobuyoshi MATSUDAIRA, who was the lord of the Tsuchiura Domain of 35,000 koku, in Hitachi Province.
In 1619, he received 2,000 koku from his father, Nobuyoshi MATSUDAIRA, who was the lord of the Tsuchiura Domain of 35,000 koku, in Hitachi Province.

sen.j: 寛永10年（1633年）、徳川家光将軍の頃、書院番士を皮切りに奏者番など務めあげた。
sen.e: In 1633, around the time of the Shogun Iemitsu TOKUGAWA, he first worked as Shoinbanshi (the shogun's body guard or the castle guard) and Sojaban (an official in charge of the ceremonies).
In 1633, around the time of the Shogun Iemitsu TOKUGAWA, he first worked as Shoinbanshi (the shogun's body guard or the castle guard) and Sojaban (an official in charge of the ceremonies).
In 1633, around the time of the Shogun Iemitsu TOKUGAWA, he first worked as Shoinbanshi (the shogun's body guard or the castle guard) and Sojaban (an official in charge of the ceremonies).

sen.j: その働き振りを評価され、安房国に2000石、下総国に1000石を与えられた。
sen.e: His dedication to his duties were so evaluated that he was given 2,000 koku for Awa Province and 1,000 koku for Shimosa Province.
His dedication to his duties were so evaluated that he was given 2,000 koku for Awa Province and 1,000 koku for Shimosa Province.
His dedication to his duties were so evaluated that he was given 2,000 koku for Awa Province and 1,000 koku for Shimosa Province.

sen.j: 土浦藩の知行も保持していたため、総石5千石である。
sen.e: Since he was a Controller of the Tsuchiura Domain, his holdings totaled in 5,000 koku.
Since he was a Controller of the Tsuchiura Domain, his holdings totaled in 5,000 koku.
Since he was a Controller of the Tsuchiura Domain, his holdings totaled in 5,000 koku.

sen.j: そして寛永19年（1642年）8月には駿河田中藩において2万5000石の大名となった。
sen.e: In August or September 1642, he became a daimyo of 25,000 koku in the Suruga-Tanaka Domain.
In August 1642, he became a daimyo of 25,000 koku in the Tanaka Domain, Suruga Province.
sen.cmt: 統一リストより、August or September 1642→August 1642に修正、the Suruga-Tanaka Domain→the Tanaka Domain, Suruga Provinceとしました。
sen.e: In August 1642, he became a daimyo of 25,000 koku in the Tanaka Domain, Suruga Province.

sen.j: 寛永21年（1644年）3月に遠州掛川に移封され、庶出の次男・千太郎を授かる。
sen.e: In April or May 1644, he was transferred to the Enshu-Kakegawa and blessed with his second illegitimate son Sentaro.
In April 1644, he was transferred to Kakegawa in Enshu (Totomi Province) and blessed with his second illegitimate son Sentaro.
sen.cmt: April or May 1644→April 1644に修正、the Enshu-Kakegawa→Kakegawa in Enshu (Totomi Province)としました。
sen.e: In April 1644, he was transferred to Kakegawa in Enshu (Totomi Province) and blessed with his second illegitimate son Sentaro.

sen.j: 生母は側室・大野木氏（家臣の娘）。
sen.e: His son's real mother was a concubine of the Onogi clan (a daughter of Tadaharu's vassal).
His son's real mother was a concubine of the Onogi clan (a daughter of Tadaharu's vassal).
His son's real mother was a concubine of the Onogi clan (a daughter of Tadaharu's vassal).

sen.j: 正保5年（1648年）閏正月には8000石加増の上で丹波亀山に移封された。
sen.e: In an intercalary month of February 1648, he was transferred to the Tanba Kameyama with an increase in the revenues of 8,000 koku.
sen.cmt: 閏正月とは正月の次に追加された月であることから、旧暦正月はグレゴリオ暦では2月頃なので訳文のようにしました。
sen.e: In an intercalary month of February 1648, he was transferred to the Tanba Kameyama with an increase in the revenues of 8,000 koku.
In an intercalary month of February 1648, he was transferred to the Tanba Kameyama with an increase in the revenues of 8,000 koku.

sen.j: 同年8月には、近藩・丹波国福知山藩主の稲葉紀通による乱心騒動にともない、城地受け取りの任を受けた。
sen.e: In September or October of the same year, he was assigned to receive the castellany in association with the maladministration of Norimichi INABA, the lord of the neighboring Fukuchiyama Domain in Tanba Province.

In September of the same year, he was assigned to receive the castellany in association with the maladministration of Norimichi INABA, the lord of the neighboring Fukuchiyama Domain in Tanba Province.
sen.cmt: In September or October→In Septemberに修正
sen.e: In September of the same year, he was assigned to receive the castellany in association with the maladministration of Norimichi INABA, the lord of the neighboring Fukuchiyama Domain in Tanba Province.

sen.j: なお、月は判らないが、この年に正室を江戸藩邸で失っている。
sen.e: Although it is not known which month it was, he lost his lawful wife in an Edohantei (a residence maintained by a daimyo in Edo) in the same year.
Although it is not known which month it was, he lost his lawful wife in an Edohantei (a residence maintained by a daimyo in Edo) in the same year.
Although it is not known which month it was, he lost his lawful wife in an Edohantei (a residence maintained by a daimyo in Edo) in the same year.

sen.j: 長晴院と贈り名された正室だったが、長男・忠俊を含め子女2人を儲けた。
sen.e: His lawful wife was given the posthumous title of Chosei-in and she gave birth to two children including the oldest son Tadayoshi.
His lawful wife was given the posthumous title of Choseiin and she gave birth to two children including the oldest son Tadayoshi.
His lawful wife was given the posthumous title of Choseiin and she gave birth to two children including the oldest son Tadayoshi.

sen.j: 万治4年（1661年）4月、丹波亀山藩において、三男・与十郎が誕生。
sen.e: In April or May 1661, his third son Yojuro was born in the Kameyama Domain of Tanba Province.
In April 1661, his third son Yojuro was born in the Kameyama Domain of Tanba Province.
sen.cmt: In April or May→In Aprilに修正
sen.e: In April 1661, his third son Yojuro was born in the Kameyama Domain of Tanba Province.

sen.j: 生母は側室・木村氏（家臣の娘）。
sen.e: His son's real mother was a concubine of the Kimura clan (a daughter of Tadaharu's vassal)
His son's real mother was a concubine of the Kimura clan (a daughter of Tadaharu's vassal).
His son's real mother was a concubine of the Kimura clan (a daughter of Tadaharu's vassal).

sen.j: 長男・忠俊没後、兄・忠国の五男・松平忠栄 (亀山藩嫡子)を養子としていた。
sen.e: After the death of his oldest son Tadatoshi, he adopted Tadahide MATSUDAIRA (a legitimate child of the Kameyama Domain), the fifth son of his older brother Tadakuni.
After the death of his oldest son Tadatoshi, he adopted Tadahide MATSUDAIRA (a legitimate child of the Kameyama Domain), the fifth son of his older brother Tadakuni.
After the death of his oldest son Tadatoshi, he adopted Tadahide MATSUDAIRA (a legitimate child of the Kameyama Domain), the fifth son of his older brother Tadakuni.

sen.j: だが、この忠栄を生家へ還し、寛文7年（1667年）庶子の千太郎（長じて忠昭）を嗣子、順養子を三男・与十郎（のちの忠周）という幕府への願い出に対し、ようやく認可が下りた。
sen.e: However, he sent Tadahide back to his birthplace and requested the Government to designate his illegitimate son Sentaro (who later became Tadaaki) as his legitimate heir and his third son Yojuro (who later became Tadachika) as Sentaro's adopted son, which was finally approved in 1667.

However, he sent Tadahide back to his birthplace and requested the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) to designate his illegitimate son Sentaro (who later became Tadaaki) as his legitimate heir and his third son Yojuro (who later became Tadachika) as Sentaro's adopted son, which was finally approved in 1667.
sen.cmt: the Government→the bakufuとし、補足追加
sen.e: However, he sent Tadahide back to his birthplace and requested the bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) to designate his illegitimate son Sentaro (who later became Tadaaki) as his legitimate heir and his third son Yojuro (who later became Tadachika) as Sentaro's adopted son, which was finally approved in 1667.

sen.j: 忠晴は御礼の進物を将軍家、老中たちへ献上している。
sen.e: Tadaharu presented gift to the Shogun family and Roju (senior councillors) as an expression of gratitude.
Tadaharu presented gift to the Shogun family and Roju (senior councillors) as an expression of gratitude.
Tadaharu presented gift to the Shogun family and Roju (senior councillors) as an expression of gratitude.

sen.j: そして、同年の閏2月9日、次男・忠昭に家督を譲って隠居し、忠山と号した。
sen.e: On April 2 of the same year, he then transferred responsibility as a head of the family to his second son Tadaaki and retired, calling himself Tadayama.
On April 2 of the same year, he then transferred responsibility as a head of the family to his second son Tadaaki and retired, calling himself Chuzan (忠山).
sen.cmt: 「忠山」→Tadayamaとありますが、号のため"Chuzan (忠山)"としました。(読み方不明)
sen.e: On April 2 of the same year, he then transferred responsibility as a head of the family to his second son Tadaaki and retired, calling himself Chuzan (忠山).

sen.j: 寛文9年（1669年）3月23日に72歳で死去。
sen.e: On April 23, 1669, he died at the age of 72.
On April 23, 1669, he died at the age of 72.
On April 23, 1669, he died at the age of 72.

sen.j: 法号：良光忠山善徳院。
sen.e: Posthumous Buddhist Title: Ryoko Chuzan Zentokuin
Posthumous Buddhist Title: Ryoko Chuzan Zentokuin.
Posthumous Buddhist Title: Ryoko Chuzan Zentokuin.

sen.j: 墓所：京都府京都市左京区の光明寺。
sen.e: Graveyard: Komyo-ji Temple, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Graveyard: Komyo-ji Temple, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.
Graveyard: Komyo-ji Temple, Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 藩主・忠昭は忠晴死去の際、江戸出府の途上にあったため、丹波亀山から松宮新五左衛門が馬を飛ばし、伊勢で追い着いて上申。
sen.e: Upon the death of Tadaharu, Lord Tadaaki was on the way to Edo; Shingozaemon MATSUNOMIYA hurried his horse from Tanba Kameyama to Ise, where he caught up with Tadaaki and delivered the message.
Upon the death of Tadaharu, the lord Tadaaki was on the way to Edo; Shingozaemon MATSUNOMIYA hurried his horse from Tanba Kameyama to Ise, where he caught up with Tadaaki and delivered the message.
Upon the death of Tadaharu, the lord Tadaaki was on the way to Edo; Shingozaemon MATSUNOMIYA hurried his horse from Tanba Kameyama to Ise, where he caught up with Tadaaki and delivered the message.

sen.j: 訃報を知った行列は急遽、引き返したという。
sen.e: It is said that when Tadaaki received the news of Tadaharu's death, his procession hastily turned around and went back the way they came.
It is said that when Tadaaki received the news of Tadaharu's death, his procession hastily turned around and went back the way they came.
It is said that when Tadaaki received the news of Tadaharu's death, his procession hastily turned around and went back the way they came.
